PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
1.  The project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) is necessary to support analysis 
and preparation of the program in accordance with the government’s and Asian Development 
Bank’s (ADB) standards and expectations. Economical and technical feasibility and safeguard 
issues of high priority protection sites should be studied in preparation for tranche-1 subprojects. 
Requirements for the multitranche financing facility (MFF), such as a sector road map and 
investment plan should be reviewed and proposed. For institutional, operation and maintenance 
of infrastructure, and community-based disaster management aspects, existing capacity and 
practices need to be examined, and required measures which could be directed by the program 
should be proposed.  
 
B.  Major Outputs and Activities 
2.  The PPTA will prepare a proposal for an MFF investment program that can lead to 
anticipated  sector  impacts  and  outcomes,  and  for  program  processing  documents  for  the 
government  and  ADB.  The  PPTA  will  cover  feasibility  studies  for  tranche-1  subprojects, 
preparation of an MFF sector road map and overall program investment plan, institutional study, 
safeguard assessments, implementation schedule, and development project proforma/proposal 
(DPP) preparation support.

D.  Consulting Services 
5.  The consultant team that will consist of international and national experts will be lead by 
an international firm. It will be engaged through the quality and cost-based selection with 90:10 
of technical and financial weight, in consideration of the indispensable requirement of high 
technical knowledge and experiences of technically complex rivers in Bangladesh which will 
bring major impacts for the consultants’ quality on the program design quality. Preliminary 
estimate of required inputs is summarized in the following table.

6.  In addition, the following surveys and supporting studies by qualified national consulting 
firms,  research  institutions,  and/or  national  nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs)  will  be 
included; flood inundation analysis, river morphology study, topographic survey, environmental 
impact assessment (EIA)/ initial environmental examination (IEE) study, and social and baseline 
survey. Further, the BWDB has been conducting flood monitoring survey, short-term riverbank 
erosion prediction study, and geotechnical investigations, whose results will be provided to the 
PPTA team.  
 
7.  The outline terms of reference for the PPTA consultants are described in paras. 8 to 11.  
Person-months of each position are listed in Table A4.3.  
 
8.  Team Leader (TL)/ River Mgmt Specialist (international) and Deputy TL/ Flood and 
Erosion Mgmt Specialist (national). They will provide overall direction and instruction to the 
TA team. Their primary responsibilities are formulating an overall program design and program 
financing  plan,  consolidating  feasibility  study  results  for  tranche-1  subprojects  including 
implementation plan of tranche-1, and ensuring satisfying all requirements of the government 
and ADB for processing the proposed investment, including MFF requirement documents like a 
sector road map and investment plan, safeguard requirements including EIA/IEE studies and 
resettlement framework, and other requirements like a gender action plan. The Deputy TL will 
also provide lead advisory support on BWDB’s DPP preparation.  
 
9.  River  Engineer  (international),  Hydrologist/  Numerical  Modeling  Specialist 
(international),  River  Engineer/  Erosion  Protection  Designer  (national),  Hydraulic 
Structural Engineer (national) and Geotechnical Engineer (national) will provide technical 
aspects of inputs on an MFF sector road map and feasibility studies of Tranche-1 subprojects. 
They will also supervise and instruct relevant supporting surveys and studies, such as a river 
morphology  study,  flood  inundation  analysis,  and  geotechnical  study.  River  Engineers  and 
Hydraulic Structural Engineer will particularly be responsible for the structural design and cost 
estimate. Hydrologist will evaluate flood inundation characteristics along the main rivers, based 
on flood inundation analysis results, in consideration of climate change impacts. His/her outputs 
will become the basis of formulating the sector road map, overall program design, and feasibility

design of structures. Geotechnical Engineer will evaluate and provide advice on appropriate 
measures  against  vulnerable  sediment  conditions  along  the  main  rivers.  Economist 
(international) and Project Economist (national) will be responsible for benefit estimate and 
economic analysis, and baseline and target setting of indicators in the DMF.  
 
10.  Institutional/  Financial  Specialist  (intn’l),  Institutional/  Capacity  Development 
Specialist  (national)  and  Community-based  Flood  Management  Specialist  (national) 
together with the TL and Deputy TL will be responsible for formulating the MFF sector road map 
and  investment  plan  of  respective  spheres.  Analyzing  current  systems,  practices,  and 
institutional capacity, and formulating required improvement of respective fields and relevant 
sub-components to be implemented under the MFF are their important primary tasks.  
 
11.  Social  Development  /  Resettlement  Specialist  (international),  Environment 
Specialist  (international),  Social  and  Gender  Development  Specialist  (national),  and 
Resettlement  Specialist  (national)  will  be  responsible  for  safeguard  and  social  impact 
assessment of tranche-1 subprojects and the overall program, and for addressing all safeguard 
and  gender  requirements  of  the  government  and  ADB,  including  EIA/IEE,  resettlement 
framework,  resettlement  plans,  and  a  gender  action  plan.  They  will  supervise  relevant 
supporting studies, such as EIA/ IEE studies and social & resettlement surveys. They, except 
the Environmental Specialist, will also explore and formulate required livelihood supporting 
programs for people in the zone of the influence of the project.  
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
12.  BWDB will be the executing agency of the PPTA, and the project management office of 
the TA was established within BWDB.12 BWDB will provide (i) counterpart staff with adequate 
logistic support, (ii) resources to prepare a DPP, and (iii) the supporting surveys and studies 
specified  in  para.  6.  A  TA  steering  committee  will  be  formed  with  representatives  from 
government agencies concerned to monitor and advise on TA implementation.13 The proposed 
PPTA processing and implementation schedule is listed in Table A4.4.
